text.text: How can I analyze productivity trends in the Pre-Biller and Biller report?

text: To analyze productivity trends in the Pre-Biller and Biller report, you can view the productivity trended over a period of time. If there is any inconsistency, evaluate the reason and determine a plan of action.

text.text: What actions should I take if there are inconsistencies in productivity trends?

text: If there are inconsistencies in productivity trends, you should evaluate the reason and determine a plan of action.

text.text: How can I determine if my daily output meets or exceeds the average daily trip volume?

text: To determine if your daily output meets or exceeds the average daily trip volume, you can use the productivity in conjunction with the average daily trip volumes. If the average daily trip volume is 230, the staff must produce 230 or more trips per day.

text.text: What considerations should I keep in mind when supplementing existing staff with additional support?

text: If the staff is meeting their productivity guidelines and volume continues to increase, additional effort may be needed.

text.text: Can you explain the significance of establishing benchmarks for productivity in the billing department?

text: There are numerous benefits to establishing benchmarks for both the pre-billing and coding staff's productivity such as: Consistent billing equals consistent cash flow, Efficient staffing, Daily and/or weekly feedback provided to the staff.

text.text: What factors can potentially impact the quality of billing results?

text: Factors that potentially impact the quality of billing results include: Paper vs. electronic Patient Care Reports (ePCR), The quality and accuracy of the PCR, Lack of training and feedback to EMT crew members regarding billing requirements.

text.text: How do different roles within the billing department contribute to overall productivity?

text: There are numerous benefits to establishing benchmarks for both the pre-billing and coding staff's productivity such as:

text.text: What are the recommended productivity ranges for Pre-Billers, Coders, and Billers?

text: The recommended productivity ranges for Pre-Billers, Coders, and Billers are: 50-70 per day 6-9 per hour Pre-Biller 80-120 per day 10-15 per hour Coder 30-65 per day 4-8 per hour Biller

text.text: How do I interpret the productivity ranges provided for each role?

text: The Biller role needs a lot of information to check and confirm, therefore the Biller productivity is typically lower to allow for accuracy and thoroughness.

text.text: How does the quality and completeness of information received affect productivity?

text: The quality and completeness of information received, automation, and efficiency in the billing department ultimately affect productivity.

text.text: How can I analyze the Billing Lag report to identify reasons for delays?

text: To determine the reason for delays, you can compare the average daily trip volume (based on a five-day workweek) against pre-billing and coding productivity. If the daily average volume is more than the total productivity expectation for either group, you might want to consider overtime or additional staff.

text.text: Why is it important to keep the billing lag to one to two days?

text: Keeping the billing lag down to one to two days allows the billing office to quickly determine what may be missing and for operations to quickly respond. If you find a trip is missing a run report eight days after the transport, the likelihood of getting or recreating a report is less viable.

text.text: What factors contribute to the calculation of billing lag?

text: The Billing Lag report measures the billing lag, trended over time. Billing Lag is the number of unbilled claims divided by average transports per workday. This measurement takes into consideration the department’s effectiveness in reconciling trips, tracking and resolving problem trips, staff productivity, and process efficiency.

text.text: How does the Billing Lag report measure the effectiveness of the billing department?

text: The Billing Lag report measures the billing lag, trended over time. Billing Lag is the number of unbilled claims divided by average transports per workday. This measurement takes into consideration the department’s effectiveness in reconciling trips, tracking and resolving problem trips, staff productivity, and process efficiency.

text.text: Can you explain the impact of delays in processing run reports on billing timeliness?

text: A larger organization, with numerous stations, and not utilizing an electronic patient care record (EPCR) system, may take one to two days to receive the paper charts extending the lag time to three to four days.  Regardless, establish a baseline that allows for the timeliest billing. The two key criteria that you need to be aware of are the average numbers of “billable trips per day” and the “total number of trips to be billed”.

text.text: What strategies can be implemented to minimize billing lag?

text: Strategies to minimize billing lag include: 1. Comparing the average daily trip volume (based on a five-day workweek) against pre-billing and coding productivity. 2. Keeping the lag down to one to two days allows the billing office to quickly determine what may be missing and for operations to quickly respond. 3. If you find a trip is missing a run report eight days after the transport, the likelihood of getting or recreating a report is less viable.

text.text: How does the Billing Lag report assist in identifying problem trips?

text: The Billing Lag report displays a billing lag that is greater than one to two days, determine the reason. Do you have trips that are not billed due to staffing or productivity?  Is there a lack of reconciliation processes leaving a large amount of unaccounted for trips?  Is there a large amount of missing information that holds up the billing for several days?  Is there a logistical reason causing a three to four day delay in getting a patient care report?

text.text: Why is reconciliation of unbilled and problem trips important for revenue management?

text: Reconciliation of unbilled and problem trips, if not managed well, results in lost revenue. This measurement takes into consideration the department's effectiveness in reconciling trips, tracking and resolving problem trips, staff productivity, and process efficiency.

text.text: What baseline should be established for the timeliest billing?

text: The two key criteria that you need to be aware of are the average numbers of “billable trips per day” and the “total number of trips to be billed”.

text.text: How do staffing levels influence billing lag?

text: Comparing the average daily trip volume (based on a five-day workweek) against pre-billing and coding productivity will help you determine if a lag is due to staffing. If the daily average volume is more than the total productivity expectation for either group, you might want to consider overtime or additional staff.

text.text: How can I use the Claim Volume and Staffing report to review claim volumes?

text: The Claim Volume and Staffing report provides an objective approach in identifying the amount of billing staff required. Measuring ongoing claim volume provides a trigger to alert you that you need to modify staffing. Additionally, reviewing the volumes by the “type” of call; i.e. wheelchair, emergency, etc., can determine the level of effort needed in the billing department.

text.text: Why is it important to know the average daily and monthly claim volumes?

text: Knowing the average daily and monthly claim volumes will help keep the billing department staffed appropriately. If you forecast future growth, use the staffing recommendations to staff accordingly. Implementing productivity guidelines within the department will aide in determining the staffing for each function; pre-billing, billing, follow-up, etc.

text.text: How can I forecast future growth using the staffing recommendations?

text: If you forecast future growth, use the staffing recommendations to staff accordingly.

text.text: What role do productivity guidelines play in determining staffing needs?

text: Productivity guidelines are used to determine the staffing for each function; pre-billing, billing, follow-up, etc. The guidelines are used to determine if the daily output meets or exceeds the average daily trip volume. If the staff is meeting their productivity guidelines and volume continues to increase, additional effort may be needed.

text.text: How should I adjust recommended staffing ratios based on organizational differences?

text: Since billing systems, processes, and structures are different, you may need to adjust the recommended staffing ratios.

text.text: How does reviewing claim volumes by call type help in determining staffing requirements?

text: Reviewing the volumes by the “type” of call; i.e. wheelchair, emergency, etc., can determine the level of effort needed in the billing department.

text.text: What triggers should prompt modifications to staffing levels?

text: Measuring ongoing claim volume provides a trigger to alert you that you need to modify staffing. Additionally, reviewing the volumes by the “type” of call; i.e. wheelchair, emergency, etc., can determine the level of effort needed in the billing department.

text.text: How do billing systems, processes, and structures affect staffing ratios?

text: Since billing systems, processes, and structures are different, you may need to adjust the recommended staffing ratios.

text.text: Can you explain how ongoing claim volume provides a trigger for staffing adjustments?

text: Measuring ongoing claim volume provides a trigger to alert you that you need to modify staffing. Additionally, reviewing the volumes by the “type” of call; i.e. wheelchair, emergency, etc., can determine the level of effort needed in the billing department. The results of this report should be used as a guideline. Since billing systems, processes, and structures are different, you may need to adjust the recommended staffing ratios.

text.text: How can the results of the Claim Volume and Staffing report be utilized as a guideline?

text: The results of the Claim Volume and Staffing report should be used as a guideline. Since billing systems, processes, and structures are different, you may need to adjust the recommended staffing ratios.

text.text: What is KPI?

text: Key Performance Indicators (KPI) are quantifiable measurements that you can use to evaluate your organization's performance and efficiency. They are measurable, objective, actionable, and can tell you what to do to improve within your processes. Additionally, KPIs initiate triggers for change in areas that you might not realize require re-evaluation.

text.text: What is the challenge to implement KPI?

text: One of the challenges to implementing KPIs is determining where to start and which specific KPI measurements fit best within your billing department. If you don't know where to start, the best recommendation is to just start measuring. The details and the specific KPI measurements will begin to fit into place once you gain more knowledge.

text.text: How do I analyze the data in Biller productivity?

text: To analyze the data in Biller productivity, you can review the productivity trends in the Pre-Biller and Biller report for consistency. It is best to view the productivity trended over a period of time. If there is any inconsistency, evaluate the reason and determine a plan of action.

text.text: How do I analyze the data in Biller Lag?

text: The Billing Lag report measures the billing lag, trended over time. Billing Lag is the number of unbilled claims divided by average transports per workday. This measurement takes into consideration the department’s effectiveness in reconciling trips, tracking and resolving problem trips, staff productivity, and process efficiency.

text.text: What is Claim Volume and Staffing report?

text: The Claim Volume and Staffing report provides an objective approach in identifying the amount of billing staff required. It measures ongoing claim volume and reviews the volumes by the “type” of call. The results of this report should be used as a guideline.

text.text: what is the use of Notes Productivity report?

text: The Notes Productivity report calculates and displays the number of notes created when the claim was in a follow-up status. The number of notes can help track the productivity of your follow-up specialists. The report displays the names of the users by their log in IDs and workdays by the range you select.

text.text: what is payer mix report?

text: The Payer Mix report is a current snapshot of the distribution of trips across the payer classed. It can be dependent upon the demographic area, the type of business model, and contracts with facilities and payers. Emergency organizations may have a higher Insurance and Medicaid percentage as contracts that typically aren’t applicable.
